items.title: Not able to install on python 3.7
Rednose setup dependency may interrupt package installation
items.body:
In special circumstance,

`rednose`  dependency may interrupt package installation. See bellow, what happening :

```
Download error on https://pypi.org/simple/rednose/: [Errno 97] Address family not supported by protocol -- Some packages may not be found!
Couldn't find index page for 'rednose' (maybe misspelled?)
Download error on https://pypi.org/simple/: [Errno 97] Address family not supported by protocol -- Some packages may not be found!
No local packages or working download links found for rednose
```

python version `3.8.2`


Does we need absolutely this dependency ? Could be remove it in order to avoid this type of issue ?

https://github.com/MongoEngine/flask-mongoengine/blob/master/setup.py#L52

items.title: Automatic model code generator for mongoengine
items.body:
I have a ready database mongodb with a very complicated structure.
I understand that I can manually define every field and write the file models.py.
But maybe there is a generator that can query the db and generate the complite file models.py?

For example, there is a generator for SQLAlchemy: 
https://pypi.org/project/sqlacodegen/ 
You give it the db and it generates the ready file models.py

Is there something like this for mongoengine?

items.body:
Hi devs,
`flask-mongoengine` needs `wheel` to be present in the system for installing the extension. I ran into a similar issue and had to take help from Flask Mailing List. Since this step is not documented anywhere in the docs, I thought it would be a good change.

items.body:
Hi flask-mongoengine team, 

since the last commit is already nearly one year past. Will this library still continue to be updated? Or the project is closed?

Thanks very much for the great work!

items.title: DecimalField precision is ignored in wtforms, defaults to 2
items.body:
Wtform's DecimalField "places" attribute defaults to 2, disregarding mongoengine's DecimalField "precision" attribute. 
One of the negative scenarios - if the document is edited  by user using wtform (say, some other field is edited), decimal value is rounded to 2 places and data is lost. 

Solved it by replacing 

`return f.DecimalField(**kwargs)`

with 

`return f.DecimalField(places=getattr(field, 'precision', None),**kwargs)`

in wtf/orm.py, line 148

items.title: method init_app of MongoEngine can't use config from __init__
items.body:
I create MongoEngine somewhere: `db = MongoEngine(config=myconfig)`
And init the app int the app.py(flask entrypoint) : 

```python
app = Flask(__name__)
db.init_app(app)  # import from above
```

It's wired that MongoEngine instance use None instead of myconfig as its config.

I strongly recommend to hold the `config` when `__init__` and check `self.config` in `init_app`

https://github.com/MongoEngine/flask-mongoengine/blob/a0b0cf80ec321d29baca743e4075101db6be7d68/flask_mongoengine/__init__.py#L128

items.title: Changing settings for unit tests
items.body:
The documentation really needs a brief section explaining how to inject different settings into the MongoEngine constructor for unit tests.

This package looks like it adds a bunch of good stuff on top of mongoengine for use in Flask apps, so I really want to use it, but I'm having trouble working out how to set things up for unit tests, which is a blocker if you're doing test-driven development. 

Say you have a main module something like this:

```
app = Flask(__name__)
app.config.from_object(settings)
ddb = MongoEngine(app)
...
```

and unit tests like this:

```
from myapp.main import app

class APIAcceptanceTests(TestCase):
    def setup(self):
        self.client = app.test_client()

    def test_fruits(self):
         """API returns list of fruits"""
        reply = self.client.get('/api/fruits')
        self.assertEqual(200, response.status_code)
```

The trouble here is that the `MongoEngine` wrapper has already been created when you import `app`. That constructor calls `create_connection` which has special test-friendly behaviour when the app is configured in testing mode, so in unit tests you really want to change the configuration _before_ calling it.

What's the neatest way to inject different settings from unit tests so the `MongoEngine` wrapper gets those?

items.title: Comparing ReferenceField to None still does db query?
items.body:
In a clean() method of a document model I have I'm checking if a referencefield of that document is None. It appears that its doing a db query because of how long it takes to compare to none.

```
class Owner(Document):
    child = ReferenceField(someotherdoc)
    other = StringField()

    def clean(self):
        if self.other is None: # Takes almost 0 time, as expected (~0.0002 seconds alone)
            self.other = SomeLogicHere
        if self.child is None: # this takes exponentially more time. (~.002 seconds alone) 
            self.child = SomeLogicHere
```

Anyone know how to properly check if the document has it without forcing a db query? Or whatever it's actually doing. The object is already in memory obviously, I tried hasattr as well but this seems to be executing the same logic that is making the above slow.

And tips and suggestions are appreciated. That .002 seconds adds up quickly, only 1k items is 2 seconds alone..

Keep in mind, everything I'm doing currently is in a local development setup and has not been tested in a production environment yet.

items.title: Handle mongouri
items.body:
Hi

With the new mongoengine and pymongo version I got an error.
The problem was, that flask_mongoengine handles the mongo uri too now.

After I changed the connection.py it worked fine for me.
I just removed the # Handle uri style connections part

```
    """
    # Handle uri style connections
    if host.startswith('mongodb://'):
        uri_dict = uri_parser.parse_uri(host)
        if uri_dict['database']:
            resolved['host'] = uri_dict['database']
        if uri_dict['password']:
            resolved['password'] = uri_dict['password']
        if uri_dict['username']:
            resolved['username'] = uri_dict['username']
        if uri_dict['options'] and uri_dict['options']['replicaset']:
            resolved['replicaSet'] = uri_dict['options']['replicaset']
    """
```

items.title: while assigning replicaSet parameter, the replicaSet is gone. This is because of the below code...
items.body:
In master branch, flask_mongoengine/connection.py, line 265:

```
if conn_setting.pop('replicaset', None):
    resolved['replicaSet'] = conn_setting.pop('replicaset', None)
```

 what is f***ing going on lol

Because dict.pop() will return and also remove specific key value pair from dict, so we cannot do dict.pop() twice.
Actually this code should be:

```
replica_set = conn_setting.pop('replicaset', None)
if replica_set:
    resolved['replicaSet'] = replica_set
```

items.title: Potentiel regression in connection handling
items.body:
I have a script that used to work with former versions of flask-mongoengine and doesn't with latest master.

It is possible that the use case is twisted and it should not have worked in the first place.

In order to test my Flask app, I wrote a script to fill a database with random data. To simplify the process, I'm reusing the model defined in the application to create the data.

So I use MongoEngine to connect to the DB, with `Document`s that inherit from flask-mongoengine's MongoEngine.

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

import mongoengine as me

# Document imported from application
# inherits from flask_mongoengine's MongoEngine
from flask_mongoengine import MongoEngine
db = MongoEngine()

class User(db.Document):

    name = me.StringField()


# Flask-style config imported from Flask's setting.py file
class Config(object):
    MONGODB_SETTINGS = {
        'alias': 'default',
        'db': 'testrtksdfdsf',
        'host': 'localhost',
        'port': 27017,
    }


# Data generator
def fill_db():
    """Fill database with random data"""

    # Connect using MongoEngine
    # no Flask app created
    db_config = Config.MONGODB_SETTINGS
    connection = me.connect(**db_config)
    # Workaround for https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/issues/851
    me.connection.get_db()
    connection.drop_database(db_config['db'])

    # Create a lot of random data
    User(name='Name').save()

    me.connection.disconnect()

if __name__ == "__main__":

    fill_db()
```

This used to work but now fails with:

```
mongoengine.connection.ConnectionError: Connection with alias "default-mongodb-connection" has not been defined
```

I got it to work by replacing `default-mongodb-connection` in flask-mongoengine code with `default` which is the value from MongoEngine. I have no idea whether this is the right thing to do or whether I should be doing things a totally different way.

In any case, I wouldn't copy the value, but rather import it from `mongoengine.connection`, so it could look like this:

``` python3
from mongoengine import connection

DEFAULT_CONNECTION_NAME = mongoengine.connection.DEFAULT_CONNECTION_NAME
```

I hope I'm making sense.

items.title: KeyError accessing connection property from the shell
items.body:
Using the integrated shell command http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.11/cli/#running-a-shell when trying to access the `connection`:

```
$ flask shell
>>> from project import db
>>> db.connection
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/.../local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask_mongoengine/__init__.py", line 149, in connection
    return current_app.extensions['mongoengine'][self]['conn']
KeyError: <flask_mongoengine.MongoEngine object at 0x7f7c1f5b7ed0>
```

This can be solved (I've try it locally) saving a reference to the app when initialising MongoEngine, but in this commit https://github.com/MongoEngine/flask-mongoengine/commit/c3716150d2ed1c04c30842e0e3664f8068ec7149 is mentioned that this is dangerous.

FWIW in Flask-Sqlalchemy a reference to the app is used: https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask-sqlalchemy/blob/2.1/flask_sqlalchemy/__init__.py#L912

I've also tried to solve it using the app context stack (see [1](http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.11/extensiondev/#the-extension-code) [2](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask-sqlalchemy/blob/2.1/flask_sqlalchemy/__init__.py#L39) [3](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask-sqlalchemy/blob/2.1/flask_sqlalchemy/__init__.py#L49) and [4](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask-sqlalchemy/blob/2.1/flask_sqlalchemy/__init__.py#L919)) and it also fails with `KeyError`

items.title: Raise exception if mongo URI doesn't contain DB name
items.body:
So this just ate ~2 hours of my life and although it's entirely my fault (the documentation does say "Note that database name from uri has priority over name."), I think it'd make sense to raise exception if no database name is provided in the URI.

If one doesn't provide database name in URI, one ends with a misleading error saying `TypeError: name must be an instance of basestring` somewhere in PyMongo. My proposal is to raise exception here [1] if `uri_dict['database']` is `None`. AFAICS flask-mongoengie doesn't provide any (official) API to (re)set the DB name and since it doesn't work properly without DB name, then this should be considered error and not allowed (e.g. by raising exception, as I propose).

If you think this is ok, I'll be glad to submit a PR.

[1] https://github.com/MongoEngine/flask-mongoengine/blob/ec5d86775f75efe842e11935a8d2709958d85ad5/flask_mongoengine/__init__.py#L94

items.title: mongomock connection error
items.body:
I'm trying to test a flask application which use flask-mongoengine and when i put "mongomock://localhost" on "MONGODB_HOST" or "MONGODB_SETTINGS" setting i have experienced an error: pymongo.errors.InvalidURI: Invalid URI scheme: URI must begin with 'mongodb://'

It happens because flask-mongengine don't expect mongomock uri like raw mongoengine:
### flask-mongoengine _create_connection method:

```
if "://" in conn.get('host', ''):
    uri_dict = uri_parser.parse_uri(conn['host'])
    conn['db'] = uri_dict['database']
```
### mongoengine register_connection method:

```
conn_host = conn_settings['host']
if conn_host.startswith('mongomock://'):
    conn_settings['is_mock'] = True
elif '://' in conn_host:
    uri_dict = uri_parser.parse_uri(conn_host)
```

Any advice?

items.title: object has no attribute 'help_text'
items.body:
Good day, 

I am new to mongoengine and flask and have been playing with the stack.  At the moment I am stuck on the above error.  My confusion stems from the fact that 'mongoengine/base/fields.py' seems to indicate that the help_text is optional, but 'flask_mongoengine/wtf/orm.py' tries to access the attribute directly, assuming that it exists.  It would be probably be safer to get it like that other attributes in that method:
'description': getattr(field, 'help_text', '')
It seems 'flask_admin/contrib/mongoengine/form.py' makes the same assumptions about 'help_text'.
What am I missing here?  Should I commit a patch for these 2 issues?

Regards
Rijk
